details.description: Mental illness is a growing concern in the UK. It affects one in four people and costs the economy about £70bn each year. It is also the cause of 40% of new disability benefit claims each year.
details.alternative_title: Summer Showcase - Plexus: What’s the bright idea?
details.content:
Plexus is a knowledge hub and open web application for people with any mental health condition that currently has them signed off work or out of employment.

Returning to work can be very difficult for people who have been signed off for extended periods as a result of mental health conditions.

“I’ve experienced this issue first hand with a family member," says Martin Vowles, Director of M/A, the digital consultancy that created and developed Plexus.

It took nearly four years for them to be able to return to work full-time, and this was only possible after leaving their original place of work. It was clear to see the multiple effects this had on their whole family and friendship group, ranging from financial and emotional to social and psychological.

– Martin Vowles, Director of M/A

Plexus was designed to use data to support and guide users in how best to cope through this process, find new opportunities and help them understand what support is available in their area and how to access it.

Plexus is developed to help people with mental health conditions in several ways. It aims to:

  • Reduce the number of people signed off from work due to mental illness in the long- and short-term. There is an increase in numbers being reported to employers. Mental illness costs the UK economy about £70bn and causes up to 40% of the 370,000 new claims for disability benefit each year – the highest recorded in Europe – according to the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development.
  • Help users understand their local support systems. If people are not aware of the services available to them, their mental health conditions can get worse and cause them to need emergency services. In 2014 over a million people with mental health conditions went to Accident and Emergency for treatment, which is often not the most appropriate service for their needs.
  • Help users understand their personal skillset and its value.
  • Help users set personal goals and daily tasks to help them track progress, set targets and prepare to return to work.
  • Connect users around the country together in ‘pods’ so they can communicate and help support each other.
  • Support family members of people with mental health conditions by helping them understand what help is available.
  • Work with Mind towards releasing its first certified open dataset.
